Essays on Policy and Women's Health /
System requirements: Adobe Reader or other PDF viewer.
Description based on online resource; title from PDF title page.
Extent pagination is PDF page count.
Advisory committee: Carl Kitchens, Professor Directing Dissertation; Irene Padavic, University Representative; Luke Rodgers, Committee Member; Shawn Kantor, Committee Member.
A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Economics in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.

This dissertation contains three studies which focus on how health policies affect women. The second chapter examines how public health policies can lead to unintended effects that undermine their efficacy. Beginning in the mid-1930s, most states enacted policies requiring serological syphilis tests prior to receiving a marriage license. Using novel county-level health statistics, I find no evidence suggesting that the policies were effective at reducing the prevalence of sexually transmitted infections. The serological testing policies had two unintended consequences that potentially reduced their effectiveness. First, the increased cost of marriage deterred marriage for young couples. Using microdata from the U.S. Census, I find that these policies delayed marriage and fertility and increased female educational attainment and employment. Second, marriage licenses decreased in counties with pre-marital testing policies and increased in bordering counties, suggesting that couples traveled to marry in less restrictive states. Chapters 3 and 4 address the effects of professional guidelines on health decisions. In 2014, to address concerns of overtreatment, a panel of experts released new guidelines on the amount of normal tissue to be excised around a tumor in breast conserving surgery (BCS) for early-stage cancers. In a differences-in-differences set-up utilizing the variation in timing of the guidelines and clinical stage at diagnosis, I find that women with stage 1 and stage 2 breast cancer receive fewer re-excision surgeries following initial BCS and are less likely to receive mastectomy after the guidelines relative to women with more advanced disease. The decrease in mastectomy is driven by patients who would have gone on to receive further reconstructive surgery. In Chapter 4, I study the effects of changes to cervical cancer screening guidelines recommending screening begin at age 21 rather than age 18. The guidelines significantly decreased the probability young women report having ever been screened relative to women over the age of 21. The delay in recommended screening also delayed receipt of other services from specialist providers. For example, I find suggestive evidence that the guidelines decreased the probability of using long acting reversible contraceptives for young women and increased the use of contraceptive methods with higher typical use failure rates.
Time Series and Machine Learning Models for Financial Markets Forecast /
System requirements: Adobe Reader or other PDF viewer.
Description based on online resource; title from PDF title page.
Extent pagination is PDF page count.
Advisory committee: Xufeng Niu, Professor Directing Dissertation; Giray Okten, University Representative; Adrian Barbu, Committee Member; Fred Huffer, Committee Member; Wei Wu, Committee Member.
A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Statistics in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.

The prediction of financial time series is an essential topic in quantitative investment. In this dissertation, we proposed two types of new models. They are bidirectional encoder representations from Transformers-based financial sentiment index enhanced (BERTFSIE) models and analysts' recommendation index enhanced (ARIE) models. Compared to statistical time series models, BERTFSIE models and ARIE models involve not only the assets log-returns but also the financial sentiment of investors' reactions and analyst recommendations individually. Furthermore, an adaptive epoch size selection strategy, an early stopping for sequential data strategy, and a novel hyperparameters selection strategy (Score voting) are proposed to solve the over-fitting problem in the training process of a neural network model when its size is large, and the training data is limited. An experimental study is conducted examining the BERTFSIE models and ARIE models. Additionally, they are compared with statistical time series models (e.g., Autoregressive Integrated Moving Average (ARIMA) model, Autoregressive Integrated Moving Average with Explanatory Variable (ARIMAX) model, and the Vector Autoregressive Moving Average (VARMA)), machine learning models (e.g., Long short-term memory (LSTM)), and hybrid models (e.g., ARIMA-LSTM, VARMA-LSTM) in terms of predicting the log-returns and direction movements of two stocks from four industries (Technology: Alphabet Inc., Verizon Communications Inc.; Finance: Citigroup Inc., The Goldman Sachs Group, Inc.; Pharmaceutical: Bristol-Myers Squibb Company, AbbVie Inc.; Retail: Costco Wholesale Corporation, Target Corporation) with three testing proportion: 10\%, 20\%, 30\%. To be more specific, the forecastability of different models is evaluated in two separate ways: the prediction ability of the assets log-returns is assessed by root mean square error (RMSE) and mean absolute error (MAE), and the prediction ability in the direction of the assets log-returns are judged by weighted $F_1$ score and weighed AUC score. Meanwhile, one step ahead forecasting and rolling forward with expanding windows are selected in the experimental study. The results of the experimental study indicate that BERTFSIE models perform almost uniformly better than the other models in terms of weighted $F_1$ score and weighed AUC score. In addition, with the increase of the validation size and testing size, the performance difference among these models is diminishing. At the same time, ARIE models have competitive performance with BERTFSIE models in some selected industries.
The Method and Mysticism of Simone Weil /
System requirements: Adobe Reader or other PDF viewer.
Description based on online resource; title from PDF title page.
Extent pagination is PDF page count.
Advisory committee: Simon May, Professor Directing Dissertation; Matthew Day, University Representative; John Rawling, Committee Member; David McNaughton, Committee Member.
A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Philosophy in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Keywords: epistemology, method, mystical experience, mysticism, Simone Weil, transformative experience.

The purpose of this study is exposition on the themes of method and mysticism in the work of Simone Weil. Nearly a decade before the onset of her first mystical experience, Weil developed a method to be rigorously applied in daily philosophical reflection. She outlines this method in her dissertation on Descartes (1929-1930). I examine the question of how Weil applied method to philosophical reflection on her mystical experiences (onset 1938-1939). I analyze Weil’s mystical experiences as a type of transformative experience in L. A. Paul’s strict sense of the term. On Paul’s view, an experience is transformative if it is both epistemically and personally transformative. An experience is epistemically transformative if the only way to know what it is like to have it is to have it yourself. An experience is personally transformative if it changes your point of view, including your core preferences (Paul, 2014). I present a thought experiment and textual evidence to motivate the claim that Weil’s mystical experiences meet Paul’s conditions for transformative experience. I then propose two epistemological facts that can be revealed by philosophical reflection on mystical experience. First, it is possible to read meaning erroneously in the appearances of things. Second, it is possible to come to hold to the certainty of a conviction for reasons that elude the intellect. My findings suggest that Weil’s late views on philosophy accommodate these two epistemological constraints, thereby demonstrating a possible connection between Weil’s mystical experiences and her mature views on the nature, scope, and proper method of philosophy. However, my preliminary findings also suggest that Weil’s early work on method may have anticipated these epistemological obstacles prior to the onset of her first mystical experience. Thus, further exposition of Weil’s method is needed to support or elucidate the claim (Rozelle-Stone and Davis, 2021) that Weil’s epistemology underwent significant changes because of her mystical experiences.
Yucatec Maya Women Herbal Healers and the Transfer of Herbal Healing Knowledge /
System requirements: Adobe Reader or other PDF viewer.
Description based on online resource; title from PDF title page.
Extent pagination is PDF page count.
Advisory committee: Ayesha Khurshid, Professor Directing Dissertation; Michael Carrasco, University Representative; Tamara Bertrand-Jones, Committee Member; Cameron Beatty, Committee Member.
A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Educational Leadership and Policy Studies in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Keywords: decolonizing methodology, education, Indigenous healing knowledge, Indigenous research.

Indigenous people around the world maintain worldviews that emphasize the interconnection between living and non-living entities and the spiritual and physical worlds. Healers in these communities believe that imbalance occurs when these connections are lost and use Indigenous healing knowledge of medicinal plants, prayers, and rituals to reinstate balance. However, healers perceive that due to the lasting effects of colonization the Indigenous knowledge is in the process of being lost. This study aims to illustrate how Yucatec Maya women healers in Belize explore their identities, agency, and empowerment using the Indigenous healing knowledge as tools of decolonization to resist and transform institutional structures. This study will use a decolonizing methodology, the Tree of Life, to explore the healers’ lived experiences through their stories of acquisition, practice, and transferal of their Indigenous healing knowledge.Keywords: Indigenous research methodology, Indigenous healing knowledge, healers, decolonization, education

The Role of Academic and Social Inegration in High-Achieving, Low Income Student Retention /
System requirements: Adobe Reader or other PDF viewer.
Description based on online resource; title from PDF title page.
Extent pagination is PDF page count.
Advisory committee: Kathy Guthrie, Professor Directing Dissertation; Erik Hines, University Representative; Patrice Iatarola, Committee Member; Shouping Hu, Committee Member.
A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Educational Leadership and Policy Studies in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Education.

First-generation, low-income students currently complete higher education degrees at lower rates than their peers. It is well established that focusing on a students’ academic and social integration during their first four semesters can aide in their degree persistence. This study aims to provide ways in which higher education professionals can support low-income first-generation students on their path to obtaining a college degree. Specifically, it investigates academic and social integration efforts that aided in their success.To further research the lived experiences of first-generation, low-income students, individual interviews were conducted with nine students at the University of Florida. Student-participant responses were coded and analyzed using NViVo12 software. The findings highlighted several ways in which Student Affairs practitioners can support the academic and social transition of their students. These results suggest that, while each students' integration experience is unique and varied, there are consistent concepts that should be considered when supporting this population of students to degree completion.
Department of Educational Leadership and Policy Studies.
Spatial Disparity and Educational Sorting of U.S. Internal Migration /
System requirements: Adobe Reader or other PDF viewer.
Description based on online resource; title from PDF title page.
Extent pagination is PDF page count.
Advisory committee: Elwood Carlson, Professor Directing Dissertation; Carl Schmertmann, University Representative; Mathew Hauer, Committee Member; John Reynolds, Committee Member.
A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Sociology in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Keywords: Communities, Education, Geographic Disparity, Internal Migration, Spatial Disparity.

Over the past few decades, U.S. communities have become increasingly unequal in terms of aggregate educational composition. Extant research shows that educational composition predicts community prosperity and community wellbeing consistently and strongly. Research on changes in community educational composition over time suggests that internal migration—movement within a country—plays a key role in such change, but this research does not often quantify or measure the role of internal migration. Therefore, this dissertation closely examines the role of internal migration in heightening or mitigating between-community educational disparity. I use 2013-2017 American Community Survey (ACS) data to estimate several measures of migration at relatively small geographic units, covering every square mile of the United States. These geographic units serve as “communities” for which I also construct a measure of educational capital (EC)—the proportion of the population ages 25 to 64 with at least a bachelor’s degree.The current study has four analytic chapters with related research goals. The first analytic chapter explores the relative contributions of origin and destination community EC in shaping the educational composition of migration flows between origin-destination pairs. The second analytic chapter examines the effect of extant community EC on net migration patterns by education group—bachelor’s degree and higher (BA+) and less than bachelor’s degree (<BA)—and age group to evaluate the potential for internal migration to exacerbate or mitigate between-community disparity. The third analytic chapter articulates population processes underlying migration-induced changes in community EC. And the fourth analytic chapter estimates the effect of migration-induced change on community EC annually and over one generation. All analyses focus on ages 25 to 64. Findings in the first analytic chapter indicate that migration flows from a single origin can have widely different educational compositions depending on destination EC. Educational sorting occurs to destinations such that destinations with highly educated populations attract migration flows that are even more highly educated than the destination and the origin, on average. Analogously, destinations with low levels of education attract migration flows with even lower levels of education than the destination and the origin, on average. Findings in the second analytic chapter measuring net migration for each community indicate that current internal migration patterns reinforce existing between-community spatial disparity in EC. Not only do communities with high extant EC receive positive net migration of the BA+ group, but these highly educated communities experience negative net migration of the <BA group. At the same time communities with low EC experience positive net migration of the <BA group and negative net migration of the BA+ group. Thus, migration of the <BA group contributes to between-community disparity in EC in tandem with the migration of the BA+ group. Further findings reveal a life cycle in this pattern for the BA+ group, while the <BA group has no such life cycle. The third analytic chapter exploring the processes of migration-induced change indicate that changes in the number of BA+ adults in communities occurring via migration more commonly result from differences in the educational compositions of in-migrants compared to out-migrants rather than the sheer number of in-migrants compared to out-migrants. The fourth analytic chapter demonstrates the magnitude of migration-induced change in EC for each community over a generation if migration patterns remain unchanged, ignoring for the moment other population processes. In this scenario, mean community EC decreases as measures of variability (i.e., standard deviation) increase. Communities already at the top continue to pull ahead, and many at the bottom see sizeable decreases in community EC over time. I also highlight exceptional cases. Overall, findings reveal a self-reinforcing pattern of selective internal migration between U.S. communities that exacerbates spatial disparity in community EC by conferring further advantage to EC-rich communities at the expense of those that are already disadvantaged.

Impact of the Current Feedback and Model Resolution on the Atmosphere and Ocean Mixed Layer over the Gulf Stream /
System requirements: Adobe Reader or other PDF viewer.
Description based on online resource; title from PDF title page.
Extent pagination is PDF page count.

Advisory committee: Mark A. Bourassa, Professor Directing Dissertation; Anke Meyer-Baese, University Representative; Allison Wing, Committee Member; Guosheng Liu, Committee Member; Zhaohua Wu, Committee Member.
A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Earth, Ocean and Atmospheric Science in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.

The atmosphere and the ocean interact through air-sea heat and momentum fluxes. Thesefluxes are critical in ocean, atmosphere, and coupled modeling across a broad range of spatial and temporal scales, from large-scale global modeling to very high-resolution regional studies and from climate studies to operational forecasting. It is important to minimize the air-sea flux errors in order to obtain accurate and realistic model results. This study investigates two sources of air-sea flux errors within the Gulf Stream region during winter months: the horizontal model resolution of the atmosphere and the ocean, and the dynamical coupling and current feedback between the ocean surface currents and the wind stress. Four different atmospheric and ocean coupled model simulations are completed with various combinations of 2 km (submesoscale resolving) and 6 km (submesoscale permitting) grid spacing. Four additional model simulations are completed using the same model resolutions defined in the first four experiments, but the coupling and feedback between the surface currents and the wind stress is included. The dynamical coupling and the current feedback lead to large changes in the surfacestress and stress curl patterns. This leads to a reduction in the ocean’s mean and eddy kinetic energy, which largely controls the Gulf Stream path. The dynamical coupling is also found to control the physical gradient related to the atmospheric horizontal momentum advection. The stress gradient largely explains the variability in the horizontal advection when the dynamical coupling is not included, while the current gradient across current direction largely explains the variability in the horizontal advection when the dynamical coupling is included. Additionally, the dynamical coupling and current feedback is found to be important in regulating the mixed layer depth and SST throughout the warm water to the right of the Gulf Stream path due to the horizontal heat advection in the mixed layer. A high-resolution ocean model is found to also be important in influencing the Gulf Stream path, as well as constraining the submesoscale vertical heat fluxes to the ocean’s mixed layer. The atmospheric model resolution is found to impact the magnitude of the stress, wind work, sea surface height, and surface currents, in addition to the strength of the horizontal and vertical winds throughout the atmospheric column. The dynamical coupling and current feedback, as well as having a high-resolution atmosphere and ocean, is further found to be important in the vertical extent of the state parameter fields, as well as in the atmospheric circulation patterns.
Department of Earth, Ocean and Atmospheric Science.
Does Timing of the Admissions Application Impact First-Time, 1st-Year Enrollment and Success in Open-Admissions Institutions /
System requirements: Adobe Reader or other PDF viewer.
Description based on online resource; title from PDF title page.
Extent pagination is PDF page count.
Advisory committee: Bradley Cox, Professor Directing Dissertation; John Myers, University Representative; Christine Mokher, Committee Member; Lara Perez-Felkner, Committee Member.
A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Educational Leadership and Policy Studies in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Education.
Keywords: Admissions, Open Access, Student Recruitment.

Two-year state and community colleges provide convenient and affordable educational opportunities with open admissions policies, which make them “value-added institutions that are uniquely different than traditional colleges and universities” (Grubbs, 2020, p. 205). Students across the nation enroll in 2-year colleges to pursue their academic goals because of distinct variations, which include flexible admissions and enrollment policies. However, the lack of deadlines at open-access institutions may contribute to entry and retention challenges for students who apply late, particularly for those who may be un- or under-prepared for college. Few studies have considered the relationship between admissions application timing, characteristics of traditional first-time in college students, and 1st-semester academic outcomes, which was the focus for this research. The study population was chosen because admissions offices have greater access to high school students through recruitment efforts such as college fairs and classroom visits. Central to this work were the hypotheses that applicants who apply early in their senior year tend to have higher high school GPAs, are more likely to enroll in the fall following high school graduation with better 1st-semester outcomes and are more inclined to return in the subsequent spring semester. The study involved an examination of admissions application data for 3,479 first-time, 1st-semester applicants who applied to a public college with open access policies requiring only a standard high school diploma or GED. Demographic data, high school academic performance, and factors related to college preparation were collected from the institution’s student information system and the date the admissions application was submitted. The study population was limited to high school seniors who applied to the institution for the fall semester immediately following graduation. The hypotheses were analyzed using chi-square tests, ANOVA, and a series of regression models. Variables related to admissions application timing, which were segmented into distinct recruitment periods to include the fall prior to high school graduation, spring of high school graduation, and summer after high school graduation, were used across all models. These periods correspond to blocks of time representing opportunities for admissions offices to implement targeted and actionable strategies to influence first-time student enrollments. The analysis of the models suggested variations in student characteristics across the recruitment periods. Students who apply to an institution with open access policies in the fall prior to their high school graduation tend to enter with higher GPAs and although they enroll at a lower rate, they are more likely to attempt and earn more credit hours in their 1st semester. Additionally, earlier applicants tend to have higher 1st semester GPAs and yet are less likely to return for the subsequent spring semester. In contrast, applicants who apply to the institution in the summer after high school graduation have lower high school GPAs and 1st semester academic outcomes if they enrolled. The results of the study indicate applicant characteristics vary depending on when first-time, 1st-year students apply to the institution, and these findings may influence strategies admissions offices at open-access institutions employ to attract and enroll traditional high school students while also considering initiatives to increase first semester student outcomes.
Department of Educational Leadership and Policy Studies.
Numerical Solutions of the Many-Electron Ground State /
System requirements: Adobe Reader or other PDF viewer.
Description based on online resource; title from PDF title page.
Extent pagination is PDF page count.

Advisory committee: Efstratios Manousakis, Professor Directing Dissertation; Michael Mascagni, University Representative; Nicholas Bonesteel, Committee Member; Jorge Piekarewicz, Committee Member; Luis Balicas, Committee Member.
A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Physics in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.

We examine two wave function optimization methods for producing the ground state. The first is a novel method for optimizing the location of the nodes of the fermion ground-state using a combination of diffusion Monte Carlo (DMC) and projected gradient descent (PGD). A PGD iteration shifts the parameters of a node-fixing trial function in the opposite direction of the DMC energy gradient, while maintaining the cusp condition for atomic electrons if necessary. The energy gradient required for this is calculated from DMC walker distributions by one of three methods derived from an exact analytical expression. The energy gradient calculation methods are combined with different gradient descent algorithms and a projection operator that maintains the cusp condition of atomic systems. We apply this PGD method to trial functions with randomized variational parameters, for simple atomic systems and the homogeneous electron gas, and the nodes are dramatically improved. For atomic systems, PGD lowered the DMC energy to the same level as nodes optimized by variational Monte Carlo (VMC). This PGD method departs from the standard procedure of optimizing the nodes with a non-DMC scheme such as variational Monte Carlo, Density function theory, or configuration interaction based calculation, which do not directly minimize the DMC energy. The second ground state optimization method that we examine implements imaginary-time time-dependent Density functional theory (it-TDDFT) propagation to periodic systems by modifying the Quantum ESPRESSO (QE) package. This implementation of it-TDDFT propagation converges to the exact energy produced by the standard self consistent field (SCF) method in all but one case, where it converged to a slightly lower value than SCF. This suggests it-TDDFT is a useful alternative for systems where SCF has difficulty reaching the Kohn-Sham ground state.
Mentorship in the Preparation and Careers of Black Women Technology Majors at HBCUs /
System requirements: Adobe Reader or other PDF viewer.
Description based on online resource; title from PDF title page.
Extent pagination is PDF page count.
Advisory committee: Lara Perez-Felkner, Professor Directing Dissertation; Marcia Mardis, University Representative; Tamara Bertrand Jones, Committee Member; Christine Mokher, Committee Member.
A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Educational Leadership and Policy Studies in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Education.

The purpose of this dissertation in practice was to understand how women faculty and mentors influenced black women's career pathways in technology. The setting for this study was graduates from a 4-year public, mid-level university in North Florida, Florida Agricultural and Mechanical University. The exploratory study design was used through a qualitative case study to investigate outcomes associated with Black women's experiences of having a mentor or women instructor as an undergraduate in the Computer Information Systems (CIS) department at Florida A&M University (FAMU) selecting technology as a career choice. The study focus was measured through the experiences and perceptions of how women faculty and mentorship shape career pathways of CIS graduates. The analysis resulted in the identification of four a-prior codes with four additional themes becoming sub-themes, and two additional themes were identified in the coding cycles. Nine total themes were identified. Findings highlighted the importance women faculty and mentors had on Black women career pathways in technology. Implications discussed for FAMU CIS department were to expand career knowledge and opportunities, enhance mentorship for Black women and improve women hiring and visibility.

Modeling Flavivirus Pathogenesis in a Stem Cell Derived Blood-Brain Barrier Endothelial Cell System /
System requirements: Adobe Reader or other PDF viewer.
Description based on online resource; title from PDF title page.
Extent pagination is PDF page count.
Advisory committee: Hengli Tang, Professor Directing Dissertation; Yan Li, University Representative; Qian Yin, Committee Member; Fanxiu Zhu, Committee Member; Jonathan Dennis, Committee Member.
A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Biological Science in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.

Flaviviruses are positive sense single-stranded enveloped RNA viruses, most are mosquito-transmitted viruses that cause systemic infection as they disseminate through the bloodstream in vertebrate hosts. The members of the flavivirus genus are highly similar in structure and genome organization, however, some viruses have been associated with neurological complications in humans, like Zika virus (ZIKV) and West Nile Virus (WNV); while others have been linked to hemorrhagic fever like Dengue virus (DENV) and Yellow Fever virus (YFV). In the context of brain neuroinvasion, viral entry into the brain can occur through different mechanisms, for example, direct infection of brain microvascular endothelial cells (BMECs) or breakdown of the blood-brain barrier (BBB) homeostasis. The specifics of how flaviviruses gain access to the central nervous system (CNS) remain incompletely understood, highlighting the need for researching the viruses’ phenotype in the context of the BBB and CNS. In our lab, we use human pluripotent stem cell derived BMECs (iBMECs) and different CNS cellular units including primary astrocytes and stem cell derived forebrain organoids to model the brain microenvironment in vitro. Comparing viral infection phenotypes between ZIKV, DENV and other flaviviruses in the BBB we seek to understand the different neuroinvasion mechanisms used by flaviviruses. We have evaluated how a variety of neurotropic and non-neurotropic flaviviruses might use different mechanisms to access the brain, which is typically protected by blood-brain barrier (BBB), we utilized iPSC-derived human brain microvascular endothelial cells (iBMECs) to study virus-BBB interactions. These iPSC-derived cells exhibited functional and physiological BBB properties and faithfully recapitulated the in vivo neuroinvasiveness of flaviviruses. We further developed a BBB model consisting of cocultured iBMECs and astrocytes in transwell setups. This model exhibited high TEER value and selectively blocked non-neurotropic flaviviruses from crossing the barrier. We next focused on developing bacterial-virus co-infection models to understand how bacterial cell wall components may alter barrier function and viral permeability. To this end, I have discovered an unknown mechanism where bacteria cell wall components may increase BBB permeability and allow for traditionally non-neurotropic viruses to establish infection in the iBMECs and the brain Overall, we were able to effectively model flavivirus neuroinvasion using iBMECs. Our research led to the description of brain-invasion mechanisms that modulate the ability of viruses to infect this physiologically relevant protective brain barrier. Highlighting the importance of virus’ ability to directly infect the iBMECs and the relationship between the cellular response to inflammation and virus permissiveness.

The Associations between Sleep, Anxiety, and Error-Related Brain Activity in Youth /
System requirements: Adobe Reader or other PDF viewer.
Description based on online resource; title from PDF title page.
Extent pagination is PDF page count.
Advisory committee: Alexandria Meyer, Professor Directing Thesis; Greg Hajcak, Committee Member; Andrea L. Meltzer, Committee Member.
A Thesis submitted to the Department of Psychology in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Science.

Due to the high prevalence of anxiety disorders and their associated impairment, elucidating neural mechanisms that underlie these disorders has been increasingly prioritized. Specifically, the error-related negativity (ERN) has been identified as a neural marker that indexes risk for anxiety across development. Approximately half of the variance in the ERN can be attributed to factors other than genetic inheritance, including factors such as parenting style and stressful life events. The present study sought to examine associations between the ERN and another factor — sleep difficulties. This study serves as a novel examination of the associations between self-reported naturalistic sleep difficulties, anxiety, and the ERN. In a sample of 221 females, ages 8 to 15 years old, we first examined the relations between chronic (i.e., over the past month) and recent (i.e., over the past week) sleep disturbances and the ERN. We then investigated whether a specific chronic or recent sleep difficulty uniquely predicts the ERN. In exploratory analyses, we assessed whether the ERN moderates and/or mediates the relationship between sleep difficulties and anxiety. Results indicated that youth who report chronically shorter sleep duration, chronically worse sleep, and recent shorter sleep duration on school days over the past week have a larger ERN. In addition, recent sleep duration on school days over the past week uniquely predicted the ERN. Exploratory analyses indicated the ERN moderates the associations between chronic sleep quality and total anxiety, as well as that between chronic sleep quality and child social anxiety. Finally, results suggested the ERN may partially mediate the link between sleep problems and anxiety. Future studies should clarify the direction of these associations via longitudinal designs.
Two Essays on Labor in Corporate Finance /
System requirements: Adobe Reader or other PDF viewer.
Description based on online resource; title from PDF title page.
Extent pagination is PDF page count.
Advisory committee: Yingmei Cheng, Professor Directing Dissertation; Anastasia Semykina, University Representative; Casey Dougal, Committee Member; Donald M. Autore, Committee Member.
A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Finance in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.

Chapter One examines the possibility of labor upgrading during the financial crisis of 2008-2009. We use granular information on the intended demand of foreign workers by publicly traded U.S. firms during 2005–2012 to examine firm-level labor decisions. The financial crisis has a negative impact on the labor demand in general, but we find that larger firms with lower leverage, higher market-to-book, and larger R&D-to-assets are more likely to upgrade their work force by requesting highly skilled foreign workers during the financial crisis. Furthermore, firms that upgrade their demand of foreign workers during the financial crisis are more productive in innovations, as proxied by more patents granted, during the post-crisis period. The evidence suggests that some firms indeed take advantage of the crisis to upgrade their labor force and such an upgrading has real economic benefits for those firms. Chapter Two examines how an exogenous shock affects analysts’ forecasts. Utilizing the art market, this study leverages artist death as an exogenous setting to explore how it impacts the accuracy of analysts’ pre-sale price estimates. In the year following an artist’s death analysts’ accuracy decreases by 14% on average. Subsample analysis indicates that the market attention and artists’ reputation are the likely economic mechanisms influencing this decrease. These findings suggest that analysts perform poorly following information shocks which is pertinent for all capital market participants.
Deep Learning-Based Prediction Frameworks for Longitudinal Data Analysis /
System requirements: Adobe Reader or other PDF viewer.
Description based on online resource; title from PDF title page.
Extent pagination is PDF page count.
Advisory committee: Xufeng Niu, Professor Directing Dissertation; Giray Okten, University Representative; Fred Huﬀer, Committee Member; Adrian Barbu, Committee Member.
A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Statistics in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.

A longitudinal study is a research design that collects observations measured repeatedly from particular individuals over prolonged periods of time. Nowadays, longitudinal studies are widely used in health sciences, social science, education, economics, and marketing. However, several challenges are raised from longitudinal studies in the real world. For example, the complex data structure and variable-length sequential data invalid the conventional longitudinal models. The long-term sequential data and missing data from incomplete experiments add difficulty to the model prediction. To cope with the complex real-world data, we put the focus of this project on the exploration of innovative methods. The main goals of this study are to seek and propose new algorithms for the prediction of the longitudinal response and the cross-sectional response with the time-invariant and time-variant predictors during the specific prediction window. To achieve the main goals, we propose four prediction frameworks, including Multi-phase Deep Learning Prediction Framework (MDL-PF), Self-attention Recurrent Neural Networks Prediction Framework (SARNN-PF), Multi-phase Deep Learning Longitudinal Progression Prediction Framework (MDL-LPPF), and Global Attention Recurrent Neural Networks Longitudinal Progression Prediction Framework (GARNN-LPPF). We conduct the simulation study on the proposed models to test the model's reliability and generalization in different data settings and display the models' behaviors and performance. We focus on the medical domain and financial market in the application part. In the first empirical data analysis, we utilize the Framingham heart study (FHS) dataset. The FHS is one of the early longitudinally-followed large cohorts and can be used to study the contributors of cardiovascular diseases (CVDs) and predict the disease progression. We conduct two experiments: the prediction of the incident CVD event during a specific prediction window and the prognosis of the patient's functional status in Heart Failure. In the second real-world data analysis, we extend our models to Credit Card Default dataset. We also have two experiments: the prediction of credit card payment default and the prediction of the remaining amount in the current month. The proposed prediction architectures show absolute superiority and outstanding performance in the simulation study and empirical data analyses. Compared with the conventional RNN-based model, the Attention Mechanism displays the advantages of overcoming the complexity and heterogeneity of long-term longitudinal data.
The Impact of Increasing the Resolution of Sea Surface Temperatures on a Numerical Model at Kennedy Space Center /
System requirements: Adobe Reader or other PDF viewer.
Description based on online resource; title from PDF title page.
Extent pagination is PDF page count.
Advisory committee: Henry E. Fuelberg, Professor Directing Thesis; Jeffrey Chagnon, Committee Member; Robert Hart, Committee Member; Allison Wing, Committee Member.
A Thesis submitted to the Department of Earth, Ocean, and Atmospheric Science in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Science.
Keywords: numerical weather prediction, river breeze, sea breeze.

The impact of including Sea Surface Temperatures (SSTs) of differing horizontal grid spacings in simulations of river and sea breeze related weather has not been studied extensively in the Cape Canaveral area of Florida. This study assesses whether simulations using a 1 km SST product, which better captures the complexity of the region’s coastal geography, improves simulations incorporating a 6 km SST product that does not define the geography of the region as well. The Weather Research and Forecasting model (WRF) was used to simulate days with river and sea breeze development around Cape Canaveral during the warm season. Simulations utilized two-way nesting with horizontal grid spacings of 3 and 1 km. Output from the 0900 UTC run of the High-Resolution Rapid Refresh (HRRR) model was used to initialize the WRF model. SSTs of 1 or 6 km grid spacing also were used in initializing the WRF model.The impact of using the higher resolution SST dataset is presented by analyzing simulations of 2 m temperature and convective initiation, which is an important factor for operational planning at Kennedy Space Center. In addition, dynamic and kinematic properties of the thermal circulations simulated using the two SST products are presented. The analyzed characteristics include the location and timing of river and sea breeze passages, which are also important for planning operations at Kennedy Space Center. Observations of water temperatures from buoys in the Atlantic Ocean near Florida’s Space Coast and water temperature sensors in the Banana and Indian Rivers were compared to those depicted in the two SST products. Somewhat surprisingly, results show that the water temperatures of the Banana and Indian Rivers, as well as the SSTs in the Atlantic Ocean, were better represented by the 6 km SST product rather than the 1 km product. Additionally, simulated 2 m temperatures were closer to observed 2 m temperatures in simulations using the lower resolution SST data. Mean absolute error (MAE) and root mean square error (RMSE) between the two SST products were calculated for the water temperatures of the two inland rivers and Atlantic Ocean. The same metrics were determined onshore for the simulated 2 m temperature based on the two SST runs. MAE and RMSE values for depictions of the SSTs and river temperatures were found to not improve in the 1 km SST product. For simulations of onshore 2 m temperatures, MAE and RMSE were also found to not improve when using 1 km SSTs in simulations. The differences in MAE and RMSE values between both SST runs for both the depictions of the water temperatures and simulated onshore 2 m temperatures were found to be significant at the 95% confidence interval. Improved simulation of convective initiation was found when increasing the SST resolution. The amount of improvement depended on the flow regime. The greatest improvement occurred during the onshore flow regime when using the higher resolution SSTs. Inconsistent improvements were found using 1 km SSTs when observed single cell convection develops over Merritt Island. Simulations of the dynamical and kinematic aspects of the Banana and Indian River breeze generally were improved when using the 1 km SSTs. The return flow of the three local breezes was successfully simulated and generally found to be stronger when using 1 km SSTs. Simulations using 1 km SSTs also were found to better locate the Banana and Indian River breezes. In addition, the use of both SST resolutions simulated stronger maximum ascents for all three breezes than found in previous studies, along with slightly greater simulated depths of the sea and two river breezes.
Department of Earth, Ocean, and Atmospheric Science.
An Expression of Religion and Spirituality :
The Piano Music of John Tavener /
System requirements: Adobe Reader or other PDF viewer.
Description based on online resource; title from PDF title page.
Extent pagination is PDF page count.
Advisory committee: Read Gainsford, Professor Directing Treatise; Evan Jones, University Representative; Diana Dumlavwalla, Committee Member; Stijn De Cock, Committee Member.
A Treatise submitted to the College of Music in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Music.
Keywords: John Tavener, Modern Composers, Pan-religious music, piano music, Religious Music.

Sir John Tavener’s music brings two disparate spheres together, his music being a bridge between the earthly and the Divine. Tavener’s works are written within the sphere of Classical music but incorporate many styles of sacred music, most notably Byzantine chant, but with large influences from sacred Indian chant and ragas as well. Tavener’s six solo piano works are no exception to his sacred compositional style. This treatise aims to show the effect of the religious and the spiritual in Tavener’s life and piano works, and how Tavener holds a distinctive place as a composer in the history of music.
System requirements: Adobe Reader or other PDF viewer.
Description based on online resource; title from PDF title page.
Extent pagination is PDF page count.
Advisory committee: Elizabeth Stuckey-French, Professor Directing Thesis; Ravi Howard, Committee Member; Skip Horack, Committee Member.
A Thesis submitted to the Department of English in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Fine Arts.

Sure Thing is a collection of short stories set primarily in Southeastern Wisconsin, in the fictional suburb of Forest Hills, south of Milwaukee. The stories take place between 2008 and 2018 and document the daily lives of the people of Forest Hills—failing relationships, failures to communicate, drug and alcohol abuse, depression, death—as well as the development of the city itself. Over the course of the collection, a father attempts to repair his relationship with his pregnant daughter, a son discovers the rocky foundation his parents’ marriage is built on, a brother turns to pharmaceuticals to cope with his sibling’s death, a friend returns home after five years of radio silence. Overconfidence is challenged. Again and again these characters interrogate a fundamental question: Are we happy here? Sure Thing follows in the footsteps of other regional writers whose work focuses on the people of the Upper Midwest, like Stuart Dybek, Emily Fridlund and Dan Chaon, among others, and showcases a variety of narrative modes.

American Responses to Regicide in the Age of the French Revolution /
System requirements: Adobe Reader or other PDF viewer.
Description based on online resource; title from PDF title page.
Extent pagination is PDF page count.
Advisory committee: Edward G. Gray, Professor Directing Thesis; Katherine C. Mooney, Committee Member; Benjamin Dodds, Committee Member.
A Thesis submitted to the Department of History in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Arts.
Keywords: 1790s, Cosmopolitanism, Early Republic, Mourning Culture, Regicide.

American conceptions of regicide rarely garnered scholarly attention, an issue this thesis addresses by examining the differing reactions to the Swedish regicide of 1792 and the French regicide of 1793. These years witnessed an outpouring of American emotions and opinions on regicide, as the discussion faded somewhat in later years. The Swedish king Gustav III and his 1792 regicide offered little for Americans emotionally, as his nation had little impact on the young republic. Americans interested in international republican revolution closely followed the story through articles that took joy in the Swedish monarch’s painful death. In contrast, Americans grieved for the 1793 regicide of Louis XVI due to his perceived status as a founding father of liberty in two nations, in addition to his connection to colonial American conceptions of mythically good kings. A few Americans challenged this paradoxical republican mourning for a hereditary authority, but their opinion formed a minority. This thesis also explores the ways Americans understood the term regicide itself. Much like their reaction to the killing of Gustav III and Louis XVI, that understanding was not constant but contextual.

Tensor Data Analysis in High Dimensions /
System requirements: Adobe Reader or other PDF viewer.
Description based on online resource; title from PDF title page.
Extent pagination is PDF page count.
Advisory committee: Qing Mai, Professor Directing Dissertation; Arash Fahim, University Representative; Jonathan Bradley, Committee Member; Jinfeng Zhang, Committee Member.
A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Statistics in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.

A large number of tensor datasets have been appearing in modern scientific research, attracting much attention to the analysis of such datasets. Tensor data often have high dimensionality and tensor structure that contains extra information. Handling the high dimensionality and utilizing the structural information is essential for analyzing tensor data. Feature screening is a popular method to deal with high dimensionality. In the first part of this dissertation, we study the smoothness structure of tensors and propose a general framework for tensor screening called smoothed tensor screening (STS). We establish the SURE screening property for STS under mild conditions. In the second part, we study the tensor Gaussian graphical model, which reveals the conditional independence structure within tensor data. With normally distributed $M$-way tensors, the key to high-dimensional tensor graphical models becomes the sparse estimation of the $M$ inverse covariance matrices. To overcome the high computational cost of the existing cyclic approaches, we propose a separable and parallel estimation scheme. We provide numerical studies to demonstrate its performance. In the third part, we study the optimality theory of tensor discriminant analysis (TDA) in high dimensions. We provide a systematic investigation on the theoretical properties of TDA. We obtain the minimax lower bound for both coefficient estimation and misclassification risk. We further show that one existing high-dimensional tensor discriminant analysis estimator is minimax optimal.

Making the Connection between High School Preparation and College-Level Math Outcomes /
System requirements: Adobe Reader or other PDF viewer.
Description based on online resource; title from PDF title page.
Extent pagination is PDF page count.
Advisory committee: Christine Mokher, Professor Directing Dissertation; Ithel Jones, University Representative; Lara Perez-Felkner, Committee Member; Brad Cox, Committee Member.
A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Educational Leadership and Policy Studies in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Education.
Keywords: Advising, Math Learning, Self-Efficacy, Student/Teacher Relationship.

The role that high schools play in the preparation of college students has long been under debate. There are differing perspectives presented by those who make up the secondary and post-secondary systems. However, the most critical voice in this debate continues to be the voice of the student. This study will provide a comprehensive review of previous studies as well as bring forward the perspectives of current students and their lived experience with math learning and their transition from a high school setting to a seat in a college math classroom. The findings suggest that more must be done to ensure that the math learning experience is coordinated and planned by teachers, advisors and the administrators that make up high schools and colleges. The study concludes with a list of recommendations that address the shared responsibility held by secondary and post-secondary stakeholders.

A Narrative Inquiry into the Lived Experiences of Black Female Band Directors /
System requirements: Adobe Reader or other PDF viewer.
Description based on online resource; title from PDF title page.
Extent pagination is PDF page count.
Advisory committee: Patrick Dunnigan, Professor Directing Dissertation; Marcía Porter, University Representative; Kimberly Van Weelden, Committee Member; Patricia J. Flowers, Committee Member.
A Dissertation submitted to the College of Music in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.

The purpose of this study was to explore the lived experiences of black women band directors at the secondary and collegiate levels. The goal was to understand their experiences that shaped them as educators and contributors to the profession. A secondary goal was to explore the personal and structural factors that served as support systems and challenges for their careers. This study looked to uncover the participants’ perception of the following questions using the methodology of narrative inquiry: (1) In what ways have participants in the study experienced support and challenges in the advancement of their careers? (2) What values do participants in the study hold as an educator? (3) How has the intersectionality of being black and female informed or shaped the careers of the participants in the study? The participants were seven black females that are current or retired secondary or collegiate band directors. An analysis was done in order to find commonalities across the data. Those data consisted of interview transcripts of fourteen individual interviews from the seven participants. The study resulted in six themes being developed: (1) racial and gender discrimination, (2) representation, (3) resilience, (4) philosophy on teaching, (5) inspiration to pursue music, and (6) support.
Development and Evaluation of a Tonic Immobility Focused Psychoeducational Intervention /
System requirements: Adobe Reader or other PDF viewer.
Description based on online resource; title from PDF title page.
Extent pagination is PDF page count.
Advisory committee: Norman B. Schmidt, Professor Directing Thesis; Jesse R. Cougle, Committee Member; Chris Schatschneider, Committee Member.
A Thesis submitted to the Department of Psychology in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Science.
Keywords: Intervention, Posttraumatic Stress Disorder, Tonic immobility.

Tonic Immobility (TI) is a common defensive response in situations involving extreme fear such as physical and sexual assault. Although TI is adaptive in certain circumstances, it has been shown to contribute to increases in negative emotions, particularly guilt and shame, along with posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) symptoms. Psychoeducation regarding the nature, prevalence, and common misconceptions about TI may help prevent or address these symptoms. However, TI is not directly addressed in current evidence-based interventions for trauma survivors. Thus, the current study sought to develop and evaluate a brief TI-focused psychoeducation intervention (TIP). Fifty-four participants were recruited based on prior TI experience and elevated PTSD symptoms. During the pilot phase, 6 participants completed the TIP intervention and provided feedback to inform revisions. Pilot results demonstrated high acceptability. During the RCT phase, 48 participants were randomly assigned to the TIP or control condition (HET) with assessments at pre-intervention, post-intervention, week 1, and month 1. Hierarchical linear regressions demonstrated significantly greater reductions in post-treatment guilt, but not shame, in the TIP condition as compared to HET. No effects of treatment condition were found on week 1 or month 1 outcomes. The current study was limited by its small mixed sample of undergraduate and community participants, relatively brief follow-up, and lack of assessment regarding post-intervention skills practice. Despite its limitations, results suggest that TIP is a promising intervention that may be used to reduce negative feelings and trauma-related symptoms associated with TI. Future work is needed to establish the efficacy of the TIP intervention, particularly among vulnerable populations.
The Intersection of Race and Gender in Sports Celebrity :
An Analysis of Naomi Osaka, Social Media, and Athlete Activism /
System requirements: Adobe Reader or other PDF viewer.
Description based on online resource; title from PDF title page.
Extent pagination is PDF page count.
Advisory committee: Joshua Newman, Professor Directing Thesis; Amy Kim, Committee Member; Michael Giardina, Committee Member.
A Thesis submitted to the Department of Sport Management in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Science.

In this thesis, I will examine how activist athletes, particularly Naomi Osaka, construct their self-identity within social media. In Osaka’s case, I will explore how Naomi Osaka’s identities as black and a woman interact with her activism and politics through social media, and if Osaka’s activist messaging is responded to by producers and consumers of social media. Do they respond to Osaka’s activism, and what dominant structures are produced, reproduced, and perpetuated by this phenomenon? The main interpretive framework that I employ is Black Feminist theory, and specifically toward examining how black women have historically been erased in the discourse surrounding social justice issues. In other words, Western patriarchal society has not allowed black women to tell their own stories, nor adequately represent themselves in the social justice discourse. In this thesis, I examine Osaka’s construction of her identity and activist ideals through her Twitter posts. These posts run parallel to social justice movements (i.e., Black Lives Matter), and sport events that Osaka participates in (i.e., U.S. Open and Cincinnati Masters). To carry out this project, I use Critical Discourse Analysis (CDA) to examine the social, cultural, and political implications regarding the language (and thus sentiments) of media and fans that respond to Osaka’s activism vis-à-vis tweets that she produces. I explain how and where Osaka’s activism (i.e., what she chooses to speak out about within the societal order) originates, if producers and consumers of social media respond to it, and what that tells us of where we are as a culture in the United States today. The results indicate that sentiments from repliers to Osaka’s activism were highly contested; some repliers agreed with Osaka’s expressed concern for marginalized groups, while others found it inappropriate for an athlete to speak on socio-political issues. Studying Naomi Osaka’s construction of her activism and politics, moreover the responses to it, will aid in understanding how mediated identities are formed in contested ways – and whereby black women continue to find new ways towards liberation from systems that seek to erase them.
What's the Phubbing Problem? Attachment, Phone Snubbing, and Couple Satisfaction /
System requirements: Adobe Reader or other PDF viewer.
Description based on online resource; title from PDF title page.
Extent pagination is PDF page count.
Advisory committee: Michele Parker, Professor Directing Dissertation; Ulla Bunz, University Representative; Lenore McWey, Committee Member; Jonathan Kimmes, Committee Member.
A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Human Development and Family Science in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.

Technology has become commonplace in day-to-day activities, permeating our interactions, relationships, and intimacy. While it allows connectedness to those that are physically far, it also consumes our attention distracting us from being present with friends, family, and loved ones. This can take place in various forms including, but not limited to, texting, social media, video games, and entertainment applications. Phubbing, or phone snubbing, is the extent to which someone uses their phone in the presence of others. Phubbing can look like partners using their phone in the middle of a conversation, ensuring access to their phone at a moment’s notice, or using their phone during quality time spent together. Phone use has become expected when people are around each other; however, limited research has been done regarding the impact it has on relationship satisfaction. More specifically, phubbing as it relates to adult attachment and relationship satisfaction. This study explored how perceptions of phubbing behaviors can inform the established relationship between attachment and relationship satisfaction for the individual and the relationship. A sample of 116 couples was recruited through snowball and convenience sampling methods. Participants completed an online survey comprised of measures for demographic information, adult attachment, relationship satisfaction, and partner phubbing behaviors. The data was analyzed using an Actor-Partner Interdependence Moderation Model, or APIMoM, to identify the moderating role of phubbing on the actor and partner effects of attachment and relationship satisfaction. Perceptions of phubbing were found to moderate the relationship between an individual’s anxious attachment and avoidant attachment to their partner’s reports of couple satisfaction. This supports the interdependent nature of phubbing and the impact it has on the understanding of attachment and couple satisfaction. Future research should explore a larger sample over time to understand long-term impacts of this moderation.

Sparse Dictionary Learning and the Compact Support Neural Network /
System requirements: Adobe Reader or other PDF viewer.
Description based on online resource; title from PDF title page.
Extent pagination is PDF page count.
Advisory committee: Adrian Barbu, Professor Directing Dissertation; Xiuwen Liu, University Representative; Yiyuan She, Committee Member; Chong Wu, Committee Member.
A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Statistics in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.

Computer vision is an interdisciplinary scientific field that deals with how computers can gain high-levelunderstanding from digital images or videos. The tasks of computer vision include methods for acquiring, processing analyzing and understanding digital images. In this dissertation, we present approaches for obtaining meaningful representations in computer vision. The second chapter proposes a new method for dictionary learning that uses Feature Selection with Annealing (FSA) to control the representation sparsity directly. This method obtains a smaller reconstruction error than LARS or IRLS and the sparse representation can be used for image classification, where it obtains a smaller misclassification error than LARS and IRLS. In the third chapter, we introduce a novel neuron formulation that can be used for obtaining a tight representation near the training examples and thus preventing high confidence predictions on examples that are far away from the training data. The proposed a neuron uses ReLU as the activation function and has compact support, which means that its output is zero outside a bounded domain. We also show how to avoid difficulties in training a neural network with such neurons. Furthermore, the experimental findings on standard benchmark datasets show that the proposed approach has smaller test errors than the state-of-the-art competing methods and outperforms the competing methods in detecting out-of-distribution samples on two out of three datasets. In the fourth chapter, we prove that a neural network with such compact support neurons has the universal approximation property. This means that the network can approximate any continuous and integrable function with an arbitrary degree of accuracy. In the last chapter, we use the feature of CSNN for few shot learning by recognizing data from a new class as out-of-distribution data and it shows good performance.
The Role of Communication in Animal Sheltering /
System requirements: Adobe Reader or other PDF viewer.
Description based on online resource; title from PDF title page.
Extent pagination is PDF page count.
Advisory committee: Andrew Opel, Professor Directing Dissertation; Michael Neal, University Representative; Donna Nudd, Committee Member; Jessica Wendorf Muhamad, Committee Member.
A Dissertation submitted to the School of Communication in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.

Animal shelters as an institution serve a fundamental role in the United States as public safety administrators and as animal welfare advocates; however, animal shelters have only rarely been researched from a communication standpoint. In this dissertation, three studies were conducted utilizing grounded theory and autoethnography to create a better understanding of communication from both shelter outsiders’ and insiders’ points of view. Analysis suggests that popular Eurocentric media relies on common stereotypes when depicting shelters, including portrayal of “evil” dogcatchers and grim shelters. However, the image created by shelter self-representation suggests a very different understanding of a growing and changing industry focused on the wellbeing of shelter animals but struggling to communicate these changes to the public. Ultimately, these discourses come to a head in the so-called “kill/no-kill” debate surrounding the destruction of animals in shelters, which has become one of the most contentious and prominent concerns for animal shelters today. This dissertation explores each of these issues in depth and offers suggestions for shelter communication practitioners and academics alike to better evolve our understanding of sheltering communication.
System requirements: Adobe Reader or other PDF viewer.
Description based on online resource; title from PDF title page.
Extent pagination is PDF page count.
Advisory committee: Diane Roberts, Professor Directing Thesis; L. Lamar Wilson, Committee Member; Ravi Howard, Committee Member.
A Thesis submitted to the Department of English in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Fine Arts.

In Metamorphoses, Ovid outlines the progression of human generations as being made first from clay, then blood, then stone. The humans made from clay represented a leftover unity between heaven and earth, which had only recently been separated according to the creation myth: “Maybe the earth that was freshly formed and newly divorced / from the heavenly ether retained some seeds of its kindred element.” Raindrops from heaven mixed with the dirt of the earth which Prometheus could then mold into the likeness of gods. Ovid describes this time as an Earth at peace, not yet broken even into separate seasons or into individual homes, when the earth was “untouched by the hoe, unscathed by the ploughshare.” I live as we all do, in a world of breakage. Between the self and others, ancestors and their lineage, the past and the present. Where do they overlap? Many myths point to the earth on which we stand as the intermediary between the underworld and ours. The soil is not a thing but a process. It is ever metabolizing, re-forming, and transforming itself. Our myths themselves function similarly: as they are told, parts of them morph and graft onto each other like a plant accruing other meanings. Composition is akin to turning over a stone to see its underbelly. There you can glimpse the breakdown of life with its peachy mush of worms, but also new creation. It is repulsive and enthralling, the slight exhilaration of decay. I write when I feel lonely, searching under stones for love. But language is only part of my search for communion. Virginia Woolf perhaps said it best in A Room of One’s Own when she discussed how women must form their own syntax, their own language. Of the woman writer she wrote, “Perhaps the first thing she would find, setting pen to paper, was that there was no common sentence ready for her to use.” The tools passed down for her to speak through had been created for someone else. I find other ways to communicate; through my feet on the earth I converse with ghosts and missing mothers. There is a pair of mourning doves that live in my backyard. Every day I see them bobbing across my brick patio, pecking at the ants and tiny insects between each sandy crack. My couch faces a window overlooking the patio, and I was sitting there this morning, wrapped in a blanket. I thought about how much I would prefer to be sitting on the couch with my mother. When I was a teenager we would sit there together often, on weekend mornings. We drank coffee slowly and read together, our feet touching as we each reclined against opposing arms of the couch. She read passages aloud to me, would pick up a book from the pile behind the couch at random and read me the synopsis on the back. This morning, alone on my own couch, I watched one of the mourning doves thud against the window. I had never seen either do this before and was surprised at the drama of the glass vibrating and the dove cooing loudly as it flew backwards in confusion. Luckily still alive, it careened upwards out of view, but a pile of its feathers unfurled in its absence. Little feathers, like bits of smoke, falling to the ground. Memories are just like smoke - there but not there all at once. I could call my mother whenever I liked, or even sit on that same couch on visits home, but I could never reach that feeling I had been remembering, never return to that time where I had yet to find my own place in the world. Before that lonesome journey of leaving home in order to find it. But it felt so real, and who’s to say it wasn’t, this trip I took in my mind? Her voice and her feet, the weight of our blanket. Writing is the thud that brings me back to the room. Its mess, its light, its smallness. But the room encompasses everything - my past, the world’s past. I didn’t feel so lonely anymore, watching the dove’s feathers in the aftermath. Everything was there with me, greeting the rest of the day and all its sun.
